   Assessment and Plan
 PNEUMONIA, BACTERIAL, COMMUNITY ACQUIRED (CAP)
   1. Sepsis: Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, temperature of >104,
   tachypnea and white blood count with bandemia. Likely source is
   pneumonia.  Lactate initially noted to be 6.1, however following fluid
   administration is 1.9. Pt received Levofloxacin, Cefepime, Vancomycin
   in the ED. Will initiate Zosyn IV and continue Levofloxacin for double
   strep/staph coverage. Will continue Vanc as pt has h.o. of MRSA. As
   below, transiently required pressor support with Levophed.
   --> Zosyn, Levofloxacin, Vancomycin
   --> Sputum cx, bld cx, urine legionella pending, resent once on floor
   --> Maintain CVP 8-12
   --> Maintain MAP > 65
   --> Continue to trend WBC, bandemia
   .
   2. Hypotension: Likely [**3-5**] infection/sepsis. Pt received a total of 5l
   NS in the ED however still noted to have a SBP in the 90s. Pt was
   started on Levophed gtt in the ED. Hypotension may be a combination of
   hypovolemic state [**3-5**] poor PO intake, SIRS and Fentanyl/Versed. Will
   continue to give an additional NS bolus and titrate Levophed for a MAP
   >65. Give his concomittant tachycardia will like switch from Levophed
   to Phenylephrine if more pressor support is needed particularly as
   there will be less beta 1 receptor activation.
   --> repeat 1l NS bolus
   --> titrate Levophed for MAP >65, wean as tolerated
   --> Will consider switch from Levophed to Phenylephrine if he has
   persistent tachycardia and requirement of pressor support.
   .
   3. Anemia: Pt has a history of Anemia prior Hcts late last year show
   approx 23. On admission Hct 24 likely artificially elevated [**3-5**]
   hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. Repeat Hct noted to be 15, will
   transfuse 2u now. Will guaiaic stools x 3, start PPI [**Hospital1 **] though likely
   LGI bld. Patient endorses over the past few days BRBPR quantified as
   enough to fill a toilet [**Last Name (LF) 3860**], [**First Name3 (LF) 77**] son he has a history of BRBPR from
   ?hemorrhoids.? GI source versus malignancy related (met prostate ca).
   --> Transfuse 2 units PRBCs
   --> Repeat Hct, transfuse to goal of 21.
   --> PPI started, guaiaic stools x 3
   --> Consider GI consult in am.
   .
   4. Pneumonia: Chest x-ray in ED notable for RLL and RML PNA, pt noted
   to have volumous secretions from his trach as well as a fever (rectal
   temp 104.4), leukocytosis to 12.6 with bandemia. Prior to transfer to
   the floor he was noted to be hypoxic requiring intubation and
   ventilatory support. Hypotension has also been noted requiring
   Levophed. Will also start pt on an ARDS protocol for ventilation given
   the appearance of his CXR.
   --> As mentioned above Zosyn, Levofloxacin for double strep and staph
   coverage
   --> Will also start Vancomycin for MRSA coverage
   --> Sputum cultures, urinary legionella ordered.
   --> Follow bcx as above
   --> Continue vent support on ARDS protocol, wean as tolerated, on PSV
   and tolerating well
   --> Morphine prn pleuritic pain
   .
   5. New onset A-Fib: Pt noted to be in A-fib new onset in the ED at a
   rate within the 200s, diltiazem 10mg IV x 2 reduced HR to 150s, fluid
   administration further lowered to 130s. On arrival to the floor pt
   received an additional 10mg IV Diltiazem which reduced his HR to
   100-120s and received PO 12.5mg Metoprolol Tartrate x 1. Given his new
   Hct tachycardia is most likely compensatory, will hold beta blockers
   and assess response to transfusions.
   --> TTE ordered in the AM to assess new A. fib
   --> Will hold beta blockers until transfusion.
   --> Dilt as needed
   .
   6. Acute Kidney Injury: Prior Creatinine noted to be 1.1-1.2, pt
   currently is in [**Last Name (un) **] with a Creatinine of 1.8. [**Last Name (un) **] most likely pre-renal
   given his current state of hypovolemia and anema.
   --> trend Cr following fluid administration
   --> Send urine lytes in am if no improvement
   .
   7. Anion Gap Acidosis: Pt has AG of 17, Anion Gap acidosis, given
   elevated lactic acid most likely lactic acidosis.
   - Continue to trend, no need for bicarb at this time
   .
   8. Hypotyhroidism: Continue home regimen of Levothyroxine
   .
   9. FEN/Lytes: NPO overnight, cardiac diet in am, replete lytes prn, IVF
   prn
   .
   10. Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, already on PPI. Hold on SQH given
   bleed/anemia
   .
   11. Code status: FULL CODE
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 62-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), sepsis, and hypotension. He has a history of anemia, hypothyroidism, and prostate cancer. He was intubated and ventilated in the emergency department due to hypoxia and was started on multiple antibiotics, including Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin. He also received pressor support with Levophed and was transfused with 2 units of packed red blood cells.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Temperature 102.5Â°F, heart rate 83 bpm, blood pressure 141/54 mmHg, respiratory rate 18 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation 99%.
* Laboratory results: White blood cell count 226 K/uL, hemoglobin 7.6 g/dL, platelet count 96 mg/dL, creatinine 1.4 mg/dL, and lactate 1.9 mmol/L.
* Radiology: Chest x-ray shows bilateral lung infiltrates consistent with pneumonia.
* Clinical status: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and pressor support, and has a history of anemia, hypotension, and acute kidney injury.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to progress if not adequately treated with antibiotics and fluid resuscitation.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and his anion gap acidosis may worsen if not managed promptly.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely to worsen if not adequately transfused, which may lead to further hypotension and organ dysfunction.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is likely to worsen if not adequately treated with antibiotics and mechanical ventilation.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's new-onset atrial fibrillation may lead to cardiac complications such as stroke, heart failure, or cardiac arrest if not managed promptly.
6. Respiratory complications: The patient's mechanical ventilation may lead to respiratory complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, respiratory failure, or respiratory arrest if not managed promptly.
7. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hypotension may worsen if not adequately managed with fluid resuscitation and pressor support, which may lead to organ dysfunction or failure.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's condition is critical and requires close monitoring and management. The plan is to continue antibiotics, fluid resuscitation, and pressor support, and to monitor the patient's response to treatment. The patient will also require further laboratory testing, including serial creatinine and lactate levels, to monitor his kidney function and acid-base status.

Summary:

The patient is a 62-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and sepsis. He has a history of MRSA, anemia, and prostate cancer. He was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation due to hypoxia. He has been receiving antibiotics, including Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin, and has had a good response to treatment. His MAP has been >65, and he has not required Levophed. He has also been receiving Fentanyl and Versed for agitation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's SIRS criteria are still present, and he is at risk of developing septic shock.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is not fully treated, and he may develop further complications such as bronchospasm or respiratory failure.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia is not fully treated, and he may develop further complications such as fatigue, shortness of breath, or decreased cardiac output.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to sepsis, anemia, or other factors, and he may develop further complications such as organ failure.
5. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's new-onset atrial fibrillation may be due to sepsis, anemia, or other factors, and he may develop further complications such as stroke or heart failure.
6. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may be due to sepsis, anemia, or other factors, and he may develop further complications such as chronic kidney disease.
7. Stoma Care: The patient's stoma care is critical, and he may develop further complications such as stoma infection or failure.
8. Agitation: The patient's agitation may be due to sepsis, anemia, or other factors, and he may develop further complications such as increased risk of falls or physical harm.
9. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may be exacerbated by his sepsis, anemia, or other factors, and he may develop further complications such as fatigue, cold intolerance, or decreased cardiac output.
10. Prophylaxis: The patient's prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP are critical, and he may develop further complications such as DVT, stress ulcer bleeding, or VAP.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue antibiotics as prescribed.
2. Monitor the patient's SIRS criteria and sepsis response.
3. Continue to treat the patient's anemia and hypothyroidism.
4. Monitor the patient's MAP and blood pressure.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and consider further treatment.
6. Monitor the patient's acute kidney injury and consider further treatment.
7. Continue to provide stoma care and monitor for complications.
8. Continue to provide agitation management and monitor for further complications.
9. Continue to provide prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.
10. Consider further treatment for the patient's pneumonia and sepsis.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure due to multifocal pneumonia, hematochezia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and acute renal failure. The patient has a history of metastatic prostate cancer, papillary thyroid cancer, and squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.3Â°C (101Â°F)
* Heart rate: 94 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 165/58 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 21 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 92%
* SpO2: 92%

The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 350 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O. He is also receiving fentanyl, midazolam, and heparin for pain management, sedation, and anticoagulation, respectively.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 7.6 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 6.6 K/uL
* Platelet count: 226 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 38 mg/dL
* Sodium: 137 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.4 mmol/L
* Chloride: 106 mmol/L
* CO2: 18 mmHg
* Glucose: 96 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): Right upper lobe consolidation and left pleural effusion
* Computed tomography (CT) scan: Not available

The patient's medical history includes:

* Metastatic prostate cancer
* Papillary thyroid cancer
* Squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx
* Atrial fibrillation
* Hypertension
* Hyperlipidemia
* Diabetes mellitus

The patient's medications include:

* Piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Fentanyl
* Midazolam
* Heparin
* Pantoprazole (Protonix)
* Lorazepam (Ativan)
* Morphine sulfate
* Levofloxacin
* Peridex
* FeSO4
* Synthroid
* Vancomycin (Vanco)

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Presumed sepsis with respiratory infection as the likely source
* Fluid responsive hypotension, now fluid replete
* Pan-culture pending
* Continue vancomycin, Zosyn, and levofloxacin for now pending culture data
* Replace right groin line with subclavian line
* Respiratory failure: multifocal right-sided pneumonia, underlying smoking history, now with evidence of [**Doctor Last Name 76**]
* Place tracheostomy for better IPPV
* Treat pneumonia as above
* Screen for influenza
* Monitor for wheezing, iPEEP
* Low tidal volume, lung-protective ventilation strategy
* Wean FiO2, okay to use PEEP titration up now given PIP's reasonable
* Accept permissive hypercapnia for now
* Hematochezia: Hct responded appropriately to PRBC transfusion
* GI consult, keep NPO, bowel rest
* Serial Hcts
* Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response: likely related to hypovolemia, now rate controlled
* Rate controlled now
* Recheck TSH given Synthroid therapy
* Check echo
* Acute renal failure: related to hypovolemia, resolving but still oliguric
* Continue to monitor
* F/u urine lytes, UA
* Goals of care: given overall poor prognosis, would address code status and discuss goals of care

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: continued decline in oxygenation, worsening hypercapnia, and potential need for intubation
* Sepsis: progression to multi-organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, liver dysfunction, and cardiovascular instability
* Hematochezia: continued bleeding, potential need for blood transfusions, and risk of gastrointestinal complications
* Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response: continued tachycardia, potential need for cardioversion, and risk of stroke
* Acute renal failure: progression to chronic kidney disease, potential need for dialysis, and risk of electrolyte imbalances
* Pneumonia: progression to multi-organ dysfunction, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and potential need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure due to multifocal pneumonia, hematochezia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and acute renal failure. He has a history of prostate cancer, papillary thyroid cancer, and squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, with a tracheal stoma and total laryngectomy. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, sedation, and antibiotics. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.3Â°C, heart rate of 94 bpm, and blood pressure of 165/58 mmHg. His respiratory support includes an endotracheal tube, mechanical ventilation, and oxygen therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen if the multifocal pneumonia is not adequately treated, and the patient's underlying lung disease is not addressed.
2. Sepsis: The patient's presumed sepsis is a potential complication, and the patient's response to antibiotics will be closely monitored.
3. Hematochezia: The patient's hematochezia may worsen if the underlying cause is not identified and treated.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic renal failure if not adequately managed.
5. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to cardiac complications, such as stroke or heart failure, if not adequately managed.
6. Infection: The patient's tracheal stoma and total laryngectomy make him prone to infection, and the patient's respiratory support may increase the risk of infection.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may spread to other parts of the lung or become more severe if not adequately treated.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's underlying cardiovascular disease may lead to complications, such as heart failure or cardiac arrhythmias, if not adequately managed.
9. Neurological complications: The patient's sedation and mechanical ventilation may lead to neurological complications, such as delirium or cognitive impairment, if not adequately monitored.
10. Malnutrition: The patient's poor nutritional status may worsen if not adequately managed, leading to further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and antifungal therapy as prescribed.
2. Monitor the patient's vital signs and respiratory support closely.
3. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation and cardiac status.
4. Monitor the patient's hematochezia and gastrointestinal status closely.
5. Continue to manage the patient's acute renal failure and electrolyte imbalances.
6. Monitor the patient's infection risk and take measures to prevent infection.
7. Continue to manage the patient's pneumonia and underlying lung disease.
8. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and take measures to prevent cardiovascular complications.
9. Monitor the patient's neurological status and take measures to prevent neurological complications.
10. Ensure the patient's nutritional needs are met and monitor for signs of malnutrition.

   Assessment and Plan
   # Sepsis: The patient continues Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   temperature of 102, tachypnea and white blood count with bandemia. WBC
   have trended down to 6.6. however he still has impressive bandemia.
   Likely source of SIRS is pneumonia.  Lactate initially noted to be 6.1,
   however following fluid administration is 1.9. Pt was started on
   Levofloxacin, Cefepime, Vancomycin in the ED. Zosyn IV was started for
   broad coverage, Levofloxacin for atypical coverage, Vancomycin for MRSA
   coverage given his h.o. of MRSA. Yesterday he became hypotensive and
   required pressure support again with Levophed as well as many IVF
   boluses.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, Vancomycin, narrow spectrum if cultures
   turn positive; will increase vanc dosing to daily as his vanc trough
   was low today.
   - Sputum cx, bld cx pending. Legionella antigen negative, will send DFA
   for influenza.
   - Maintain MAP > 65, weaning levophed as tolerated.
   - Continue to trend WBC
   # Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a bicarb of 13 and a pH on ABG of
   7.21.  His AG is 14.  Nonanion gap metabolic acidosis likely secondary
   to decreased ventilatory compensation and the large amount of NS he
   received yesterday.
   - Support his BP as below to maintain pefusion to his kidneys.
   - Will attempt to increase his tidal volume to induce a respiratory
   alkalosis to help compensate for his acidosis.
   - Continue to follow his pH on ABGs.
   # Anemia: Pt has a history of Anemia prior Hcts late last year show
   approx 23. On admission Hct 24 likely artificially elevated [**3-5**]
   hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. Repeat Hct noted to be 15 last night and
   23.8 this s/p 2units two days ago.  Yesterday am his Hct was again low
   at 21.8 so he was transfused another 2 units of PRBC (for a total of 4
   units).  No further clinical evidence of bleeding.
   - Appreciate GI consult, will f/u recs
   - Will address goals of care at the family meeting today before
   deciding if to scope.
   - Q8H hct checks
   - Active type and screen
   # Pneumonia: Chest x-ray today looks worse. Hypotension returned
   yesterday requiring Levophed to be restarted. Pt started on ARDs
   protocol though he is taking in volume greater than 6cc/kg.  Urinary
   legionella negative.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin with increased vanc
   dosing as above.
   - Sputum cultures, DFA ordered
   - Follow bcx as above
   - Continue vent support on ARDS protocol, wean as tolerated, on CMV
   - Wean Versed and Fentanyl gtt as tolerated
   # New onset A-Fib: Pt noted to be in A-fib new onset in the ED which
   resolved once in the ICU.  He has been in sinus rhythm.
   - If A-fib recurs again at rate >100 consider starting digoxin vs
   amiodarone.
   - Monitor on tele
   # Acute Kidney Injury: The patient
s Cr increased back to 1.8 (from
   1.4). Prior Creatinine noted to be 1.1-1.2.  [**Last Name (un) **] most likely pre-renal
   vs ATN given his recent hypotension. Pt still having poor urine output
   which has been unresponsive to IVF.
   - trend Cr
   - check urinary electrolytes
   # Stoma: Pt currently has stoma, given his clinical picture he will
   likely require intubation for several days. Will discuss with ENT
   whether a trach would be better suited for ventilator treatment rather
   than the stoma.
   # Hypothyroidism:  TSH was normal at 3.0.
   -  Continue home regimen of Levothyroxine.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO while requiring pressors
   Glycemic Control:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 62-year-old Asian male admitted to the ICU with sepsis, pneumonia, and acute kidney injury. He has a history of anemia, hypothyroidism, and MRSA.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 101.5Â°F, HR 57 bpm, BP 98/45 mmHg, RR 15 insp/min, SpO2 98%
* Respiratory support: Intubated and mechanically ventilated on CMV/ASSIST mode with a tidal volume of 350 mL, PEEP 12 cmH2O, and FiO2 50%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Arterial line, central venous catheter, and pulmonary artery catheter in place
* Laboratory results:
	+ Complete Blood Count (CBC): WBC 6.6, Hct 23.8, Platelet count 226
	+ Blood chemistry: Creatinine 1.8 mg/dL, BUN 86 mg/dL, Glucose 96 mg/dL
	+ Electrolytes: Na 143 mEq/L, K 4.2 mEq/L, Ca 6.9 mg/dL, Mg 2.1 mg/dL, PO4 5.6 mg/dL
* Medications:
	+ Antibiotics: Zosyn, Levofloxacin, Vancomycin
	+ Vasopressors: Levophed
	+ Sedatives: Fentanyl, Midazolam
	+ Other medications: Pantoprazole, Levothyroxine

The patient's condition is complex, and several potential medical complications can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient's continued tachycardia, temperature, and white blood cell count with bandemia indicate ongoing sepsis. The likely source of SIRS is pneumonia.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's chest x-ray shows worsening lung disease, and he is at risk for further respiratory decline.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level has increased to 1.8 mg/dL, and his urine output is poor. He may require further interventions to support kidney function.
4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's bicarbonate level is low, and his pH on ABG is 7.21. He may require further interventions to correct his acid-base imbalance.
5. Anemia: The patient's Hct level is 23.8, and he has a history of anemia. He may require further transfusions or other interventions to address his anemia.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's TSH level is normal, but he has a history of hypothyroidism. He should continue to receive his home regimen of Levothyroxine.
7. New onset A-Fib: The patient has had a recent episode of atrial fibrillation, and he may be at risk for further arrhythmias.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin antibiotics
2. Maintain MAP > 65 and wean Levophed as tolerated
3. Trend WBC count and monitor for signs of sepsis
4. Continue respiratory support on CMV/ASSIST mode
5. Wean sedatives and vasopressors as tolerated
6. Monitor for signs of AKI and adjust fluid management accordingly
7. Consider further interventions to address metabolic acidosis
8. Continue to monitor for signs of anemia and consider further transfusions
9. Monitor for signs of hypothyroidism and continue home regimen of Levothyroxine
10. Discuss code status and goals of care with the family at the family meeting today.

Summary:

The patient is a 62-year-old Asian male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of pneumonia. He has been receiving mechanical ventilation and has been treated with antibiotics. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 101.5Â°F, blood pressure of 98/45 mmHg, and heart rate of 57 beats per minute. His oxygen saturation is 98% on 50% FiO2. He has a midline placed for now, and his hemoglobin has increased to 28.4% after receiving four units of packed red blood cells.

The patient's TTE showed mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved global and regional biventricular systolic function, mild aortic regurgitation, and mild pulmonary hypertension. His TSH was 3.0, and his SP's decreased to the 70's, prompting the administration of a 1 L NS bolus and the start of his second unit of blood.

The patient's UOP was low, so he received a 500 CC bolus twice. His cultures were sent after his temperature spiked to 101.5Â°F. His review of systems is unchanged from admission, except for the noted changes.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's temperature of 101.5Â°F and the administration of antibiotics suggest the possibility of sepsis.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's need for mechanical ventilation and his low tidal volumes suggest the possibility of respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient's TTE showed mild aortic regurgitation and mild pulmonary hypertension, which could lead to cardiac complications such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
4. Bleeding: The patient's administration of blood products and his low platelet count suggest the possibility of bleeding complications.
5. Infection: The patient's cultures were sent after his temperature spiked, suggesting the possibility of infection.
6. Fluid Overload: The patient's fluid balance is positive, which could lead to fluid overload and cardiovascular complications.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's low UOP and the administration of antibiotics suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal complications such as diarrhea or constipation.

   Assessment and Plan
   85 y.o. Male w/ papillary thyroid CA s/p thyroidectomy with radioactive
   iodine ablation, SCC of the larynx s/p total laryngectomy w/ modified
   radical neck dissection with stoma, metastatic prostate cancer with
   metastatic lesions to the bone presenting to the ED with 2day history
   of fevers, chills, fatigue, poor PO intake and non-productive cough now
   septic and intubated.
   # Sepsis: The patient continues Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   temperature of 102, tachypnea and white blood count with bandemia. WBC
   have trended down to 6.6. however he still has impressive bandemia.
   Likely source of SIRS is pneumonia.  Lactate initially noted to be 6.1,
   however following fluid administration is 1.9. Pt was started on
   Levofloxacin, Cefepime, Vancomycin in the ED. Zosyn IV was started for
   broad coverage, Levofloxacin for atypical coverage, Vancomycin for MRSA
   coverage given his h.o. of MRSA. Yesterday he became hypotensive and
   required pressure support again with Levophed as well as many IVF
   boluses.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, Vancomycin, narrow spectrum if cultures
   turn positive; will increase vanc dosing to daily as his vanc trough
   was low today.
   - Sputum cx, bld cx pending. Legionella antigen negative, will send DFA
   for influenza.
   - Maintain MAP > 65, weaning levophed as tolerated.
   - Continue to trend WBC
   # Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a bicarb of 13 and a pH on ABG of
   7.21.  His AG is 14.  Nonanion gap metabolic acidosis likely secondary
   to decreased ventilatory compensation and the large amount of NS he
   received yesterday.
   - Support his BP as below to maintain pefusion to his kidneys.
   - Will attempt to increase his tidal volume to induce a respiratory
   alkalosis to help compensate for his acidosis.
   - Continue to follow his pH on ABGs.
   # Anemia: Pt has a history of Anemia prior Hcts late last year show
   approx 23. On admission Hct 24 likely artificially elevated [**3-5**]
   hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. Repeat Hct noted to be 15 last night and
   23.8 this s/p 2units two days ago.  Yesterday am his Hct was again low
   at 21.8 so he was transfused another 2 units of PRBC (for a total of 4
   units).  No further clinical evidence of bleeding.
   - Appreciate GI consult, will f/u recs
   - Will address goals of care at the family meeting today before
   deciding if to scope.
   - Q8H hct checks
   - Active type and screen
   # Pneumonia: Chest x-ray today looks worse. Hypotension returned
   yesterday requiring Levophed to be restarted. Pt started on ARDs
   protocol though he is taking in volume greater than 6cc/kg.  Urinary
   legionella negative.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin with increased vanc
   dosing as above.
   - Sputum cultures, DFA ordered
   - Follow bcx as above
   - Continue vent support on ARDS protocol, wean as tolerated, on CMV
   - Wean Versed and Fentanyl gtt as tolerated
   # New onset A-Fib: Pt noted to be in A-fib new onset in the ED which
   resolved once in the ICU.  He has been in sinus rhythm.
   - If A-fib recurs again at rate >100 consider starting digoxin vs
   amiodarone.
   - Monitor on tele
   # Acute Kidney Injury: The patient
s Cr increased back to 1.8 (from
   1.4). Prior Creatinine noted to be 1.1-1.2.  [**Last Name (un) **] most likely pre-renal
   vs ATN given his recent hypotension. Pt still having poor urine output
   which has been unresponsive to IVF.
   - trend Cr
   - check urinary electrolytes
   # Stoma: Pt currently has stoma, given his clinical picture he will
   likely require intubation for several days. Will discuss with ENT
   whether a trach would be better suited for ventilator treatment rather
   than the stoma.
   # Hypothyroidism:  TSH was normal at 3.0.
   -  Continue home regimen of Levothyroxine.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO while requiring pressors
   Glycemic Control:

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following medical complications are potential concerns:

1. Sepsis: The patient continues to meet SIRS criteria with tachycardia, temperature of 102, tachypnea, and white blood count with bandemia. The likely source of SIRS is pneumonia. The patient's lactate level has improved with fluid administration, but the patient remains at risk for further complications.
2. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a bicarbonate level of 13 and a pH on ABG of 7.21, indicating a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. The patient's acidosis is likely secondary to decreased ventilatory compensation and the large amount of NS received yesterday. The patient's pH on ABGs will be closely monitored.
3. Anemia: The patient has a history of anemia, and his Hct has been artificially elevated due to hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. The patient has received 4 units of PRBC, and his Hct has improved to 28.4. However, the patient's anemia may continue to be a concern.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's chest x-ray shows worsening pneumonia, and he has required increased ventilatory support. The patient's urinary legionella antigen is negative, but DFA has been ordered to confirm the diagnosis.
5. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's Cr has increased to 1.8, and his urinary output remains poor. The patient's kidney function will be closely monitored, and treatment will be adjusted as necessary.
6. New onset A-Fib: The patient experienced new onset A-Fib in the ED, which resolved once in the ICU. The patient will be monitored for any recurrence.
7. Stoma: The patient currently has a stoma, and it is likely that he will require intubation for several days. The patient's ENT will be consulted to determine whether a trach would be better suited for ventilator treatment rather than the stoma.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continuing Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin with increased vanc dosing as above.
2. Sputum cultures, DFA, and Legionella antigen will be ordered to confirm the diagnosis of pneumonia.
3. The patient's MAP will be maintained above 65, and levophed will be weaned as tolerated.
4. The patient's WBC will be trended, and he will be monitored for any signs of bleeding.
5. The patient's acidosis will be closely monitored, and treatment will be adjusted as necessary.
6. The patient's anemia will be monitored, and further treatment will be considered as necessary.
7. The patient's kidney function will be closely monitored, and treatment will be adjusted as necessary.
8. The patient's A-Fib will be monitored for any recurrence, and treatment will be adjusted as necessary.
9. The patient's stoma will be monitored, and treatment will be adjusted as necessary.

The patient's family will be consulted today to discuss his goals of care and whether he should be scoped.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 62-year-old Asian male who was admitted to the ICU with sepsis, hypotension, anemia, pneumonia, and new-onset atrial fibrillation. He has a history of anemia, prostate cancer, and MRSA.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 38.6Â°C (102.5Â°F)
* Heart rate: 57-94 bpm
* Blood pressure: 98/45 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 15-21 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%

The patient has been treated with antibiotics, including Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin, and has been started on a pressor agent, Levophed. He has also been given a 1 L NS bolus and has been restarted on his second unit of blood.

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* Hemoglobin: 9.2 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 23.8%
* White blood cell count: 6.6 x 10^9/L
* Platelet count: 226 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.9 mmol/L

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved global and regional biventricular systolic function
* Mild aortic regurgitation
* Mild pulmonary hypertension
* Biatrial enlargement
* Soft, non-tender abdomen
* No edema or organomegaly

The patient's diagnosis is:

* Sepsis: Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, temperature of 102Â°F, tachypnea, and white blood count with bandemia. Likely source of SIRS is pneumonia.
* Hypotension: May be due to hypovolemic state, poor PO intake, SIRS, and Fentanyl/Versed.
* Anemia: Patient has a history of anemia and has been transfused with 4 units of packed red blood cells.
* Pneumonia: Chest x-ray shows RLL and RML PNA.
* Atrial fibrillation: New-onset atrial fibrillation with a rate within the 200s, which has since resolved.

The patient's plan is:

* Continue antibiotics, including Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin.
* Repeat Hct at 1200 and transfuse to goal of 25.
* PPI started, guaiac stools x 3.
* GI consult today, f/u GI recs.
* Continue vent support on ARDS protocol, wean as tolerated.
* Titrate Versed and Fentanyl gtt for anxiety control.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine has increased to 1.8 mg/dL, and he has poor urine output.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is on ventilatory support and may require weaning.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has had new-onset atrial fibrillation and may be at risk for other cardiac arrhythmias.
* Sepsis: The patient has sepsis and may develop further complications.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia and may require further transfusions.
* Pneumonia: The patient has pneumonia and may require further treatment.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 62-year-old Asian male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis, pneumonia, and acute kidney injury. The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.5Â°F (38.6Â°C)
* Blood pressure: 98/45 mmHg
* Heart rate: 57 bpm
* Respiratory rate: 15 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* Hemoglobin: 23.8 g/dL (pre-transfusion)
* Hematocrit: 28.4% (post-transfusion)

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 6.6 x 10^9/L
* Bandemia: 44.0%
* Lactic acid: 1.9 mmol/L
* Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 27.9 mg/dL
* Sodium: 143 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.2 mmol/L
* Chloride: 116 mmol/L
* CO2: 47 mmol/L
* pH: 7.21
* Bicarbonate: 13 mmol/L
* Anion gap: 14 mmol/L

The patient's medical history includes a history of anemia, hypothyroidism, and prostate cancer. The patient has a history of bleeding from hemorrhoids, and the patient's family history includes a history of MRSA.

The patient's current medications include:

* Piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Levofloxacin
* Vancomycin
* Fentanyl
* Midazolam (Versed)
* Norepinephrine (Levophed)
* Pantoprazole (Protonix)

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Supportive care for sepsis and pneumonia
* Antibiotics for MRSA coverage
* Fluid resuscitation for hypovolemia
* Vasopressors for hypotension
* Sedation and analgesia for comfort
* Monitoring for acute kidney injury

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued sepsis and pneumonia
* Acute kidney injury
* Hypothyroidism
* Anemia
* Hypovolemia
* Hypotension
* Tachycardia
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* GI bleeding
* Infection

The patient's current condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities. The patient has been diagnosed with presumed sepsis, respiratory failure, hematocritemia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and acute renal failure. The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and antibiotics.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.6Â°C (101.5Â°F)
* Heart rate: 57 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 111/54 mmHg (97/33 mmHg - 147/75 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute (bpm)
* SpO2: 99%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 6.6+3
* Hematocrit: 23.8
* Platelet count: 226
* Creatinine: 1.4
* Troponin-T: <0.01
* Lactic acid: 1.0 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.9
* Calcium: 6.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 5.6 mg/dL

The patient's medical history is significant for smoking, and they have a history of respiratory failure. The patient has been prescribed vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and levofloxacin for presumed sepsis.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuous monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results
* Maintenance of mechanical ventilation and vasopressors
* Antibiotic therapy
* Pulmonary toilet and oxygen therapy
* Fluid management
* Nutrition and glycemic control
* Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction
* Respiratory failure
* Hemodynamic instability
* Acute kidney injury
* Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
* Hypovolemia
* Hyperchloridemia
* Nongap metabolic acidemia
* Hypoglycemia
* Hypocalcemia
* Hypomagnesemia
* Hyperphosphatemia
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia

Given the patient's critical condition, it is essential to closely monitor their vital signs, laboratory results, and overall clinical status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with a presumed sepsis-related respiratory infection, fluid responsive hypotension, and respiratory failure. The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis may lead to organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury, liver dysfunction, or cardiovascular instability.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, requiring increased ventilatory support or consideration of tracheostomy.
3. Hematocrit response: The patient's hematocrit response to PRBC transfusion may be inadequate, leading to further bleeding or anemia.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress, requiring further management and consideration of renal replacement therapy.
5. Nongap metabolic acidemia: The patient's nongap metabolic acidemia may worsen, requiring further management and consideration of acid-base disorders.
6. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular instability may worsen, requiring further management and consideration of cardiovascular interventions.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding may worsen, requiring further management and consideration of gastrointestinal interventions.
8. Infection-related complications: The patient's infection may lead to complications such as pneumonia, septic shock, or disseminated intravascular coagulation.
9. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status may worsen, requiring further management and consideration of neurological interventions.

In terms of the patient's current status, the following points are notable:

* The patient's respiratory status is critical, with evidence of multifocal right-sided pneumonia and ventilator dyssynchrony.
* The patient's cardiovascular status is unstable, with hypotension and requirement for vasopressors.
* The patient's renal function is impaired, with acute renal failure and nongap metabolic acidemia.
* The patient's hematocrit response to PRBC transfusion has been adequate, but further monitoring is required.
* The patient's electrolyte and acid-base status is abnormal, requiring further management and monitoring.
* The patient's neurological status is uncertain, with a Glasgow Coma Scale score not provided.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are required to prevent complications and optimize outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
 ANEMIA, ACUTE, SECONDARY TO BLOOD LOSS (HEMORRHAGE, BLEEDING)
 ACIDOSIS, METABOLIC
 HYPOTENSION (NOT SHOCK)
 PNEUMONIA, BACTERIAL, COMMUNITY ACQUIRED (CAP)
   85 y.o. Male w/ papillary thyroid CA s/p thyroidectomy with radioactive
   iodine ablation, SCC of the larynx s/p total laryngectomy w/ modified
   radical neck dissection with stoma, metastatic prostate cancer with
   metastatic lesions to the bone presenting to the ED with 2day history
   of fevers, chills, fatigue, poor PO intake and non-productive cough now
   septic and intubated.
   # Sepsis: The patient continues Meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   temperature of 102, tachypnea and white blood count with bandemia. WBC
   have trended down to 6.6. however he still has impressive bandemia.
   Likely source of SIRS is pneumonia.  Lactate initially noted to be 6.1,
   however following fluid administration is 1.9. Pt was started on
   Levofloxacin, Cefepime, Vancomycin in the ED. Zosyn IV was started for
   broad coverage, Levofloxacin for atypical coverage, Vancomycin for MRSA
   coverage given his h.o. of MRSA. Yesterday he became hypotensive and
   required pressure support again with Levophed as well as many IVF
   boluses.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, Vancomycin, narrow spectrum if cultures
   turn positive; will increase vanc dosing to daily as his vanc trough
   was low today.
   - Sputum cx, bld cx pending. Legionella antigen negative, will send DFA
   for influenza.
   - Maintain MAP > 65, weaning levophed as tolerated.
   - Continue to trend WBC
   # Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a bicarb of 13 and a pH on ABG of
   7.21.  His AG is 14.  Nonanion gap metabolic acidosis likely secondary
   to decreased ventilatory compensation and the large amount of NS he
   received yesterday.
   - Support his BP as below to maintain pefusion to his kidneys.
   - Will attempt to increase his tidal volume to induce a respiratory
   alkalosis to help compensate for his acidosis.
   - Continue to follow his pH on ABGs.
   # Anemia: Pt has a history of Anemia prior Hcts late last year show
   approx 23. On admission Hct 24 likely artificially elevated [**3-5**]
   hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. Repeat Hct noted to be 15 last night and
   23.8 this s/p 2units two days ago.  Yesterday am his Hct was again low
   at 21.8 so he was transfused another 2 units of PRBC (for a total of 4
   units).  No further clinical evidence of bleeding.
   - Appreciate GI consult, will f/u recs
   - Will address goals of care at the family meeting today before
   deciding if to scope.
   - Q8H hct checks
   - Active type and screen
   # Pneumonia: Chest x-ray today looks worse. Hypotension returned
   yesterday requiring Levophed to be restarted. Pt started on ARDs
   protocol though he is taking in volume greater than 6cc/kg.  Urinary
   legionella negative.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin with increased vanc
   dosing as above.
   - Sputum cultures, DFA ordered
   - Follow bcx as above
   - Continue vent support on ARDS protocol, wean as tolerated, on CMV
   - Wean Versed and Fentanyl gtt as tolerated
   # New onset A-Fib: Pt noted to be in A-fib new onset in the ED which
   resolved once in the ICU.  He has been in sinus rhythm.
   - If A-fib recurs again at rate >100 consider starting digoxin vs
   amiodarone.
   - Monitor on tele
   # Acute Kidney Injury: The patient
s Cr increased back to 1.8 (from
   1.4). Prior Creatinine noted to be 1.1-1.2.  [**Last Name (un) **] most likely pre-renal
   vs ATN given his recent hypotension. Pt still having poor urine output
   which has been unresponsive to IVF.
   - trend Cr
   - check urinary electrolytes
   # Stoma: Pt currently has stoma, given his clinical picture he will
   likely require intubation for several days. Will discuss with ENT
   whether a trach would be better suited for ventilator treatment rather
   than the stoma.
   # Hypothyroidism:  TSH was normal at 3.0.
   -  Continue home regimen of Levothyroxine.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Acute kidney injury progression
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Hypothyroidism-related complications

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

**Patient's Condition:**

The patient is a 85-year-old male with a complex medical history, including papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He is currently intubated and in the ICU due to septic shock, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and acute kidney injury (AKI).

**Medical Complications:**

1. **Sepsis:** The patient has been septic since admission, with a white blood cell count trending down but still showing impressive bandemia. The likely source of SIRS is pneumonia.
2. **Acidosis:** The patient has metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to decreased ventilatory compensation and large amounts of normal saline received yesterday.
3. **Anemia:** The patient has a history of anemia, and his hematocrit (Hct) has been fluctuating. He has received 4 units of packed red blood cells (PRBC) and will continue to receive transfusions as needed.
4. **Pneumonia:** The patient has pneumonia, with worsening chest x-ray findings and hypotension requiring Levophed support.
5. **Acute Kidney Injury (AKI):** The patient's creatinine has increased to 1.8, and he has poor urine output, likely secondary to pre-renal or ATN.
6. **New Onset Atrial Fibrillation (A-Fib):** The patient experienced new onset A-Fib in the ED, which resolved in the ICU.

**Assessment and Plan:**

1. **Sepsis:** Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin, and narrow spectrum antibiotics if cultures turn positive.
2. **Acidosis:** Support blood pressure to maintain perfusion to kidneys, attempt to increase tidal volume to induce respiratory alkalosis, and continue to follow pH on ABGs.
3. **Anemia:** Appreciate GI consult, address goals of care at family meeting, and continue to monitor Hct and transfusion needs.
4. **Pneumonia:** Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin, and follow chest x-ray findings.
5. **Acute Kidney Injury (AKI):** Trend creatinine, check urinary electrolytes, and consider dialysis if necessary.
6. **New Onset A-Fib:** Monitor for recurrence and consider starting digoxin or amiodarone if necessary.

**ICU Care:**

1. **Nutrition:** Continue to provide nutritional support as needed.
2. **Glycemic Control:** Monitor blood glucose levels and adjust insulin therapy as necessary.
3. **Lines:** Monitor central venous catheter, arterial line, and urinary catheter.
4. **Prophylaxis:** Continue stress ulcer prophylaxis, DVT prophylaxis, and VAP prophylaxis.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP):** The patient is at high risk for VAP due to prolonged intubation.
2. **Catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI):** The patient is at risk for CAUTI due to urinary catheterization.
3. **Deep vein thrombosis (DVT):** The patient is at risk for DVT due to immobility and central venous catheterization.
4. **Pulmonary embolism (PE):** The patient is at risk for PE due to immobility and DVT.
5. **Cardiac arrhythmias:** The patient is at risk for cardiac arrhythmias due to his complex medical history and medication regimen.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status.
2. Adjust medications and therapies as necessary to manage the patient's medical complications.
3. Consider transferring the patient to a cardiac ICU or a medical-surgical ICU if necessary.
4. Discuss with the patient's family and healthcare providers the goals of care and potential outcomes.

   85 y.o. Male w/ papillary thyroid CA s/p thyroidectomy with radioactive
   iodine ablation, SCC of the larynx s/p total laryngectomy w/ modified
   radical neck dissection with stoma, metastatic prostate cancer with

   Vancomycin for MRSA coverage given his h.o. of MRSA. Yesterday he

   well as frequent IVF boluses. Today he has been able to wean off the
   levophed gtt.

   hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. Pt received 2units PRBC following a
   morning Hct of 15. Currently his Hct has been stable now at 30, will

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 85-year-old male with a complex medical history, including papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He is currently intubated and septic, with a diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia, acute kidney injury, and metabolic acidosis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1Â°C, heart rate of 56 bpm, and blood pressure of 120/60 mmHg. His respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 12 cmH2O.

The patient has received multiple antibiotics, including vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and levofloxacin, and has been started on a broad-spectrum antibiotic regimen. His blood cultures are pending, and he has been treated for suspected sepsis.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.7 g/dL and a hematocrit of 28.9%. His white blood cell count is 11.5 K/uL, with a band count of 44.0%. His creatinine level has increased to 2.7 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen level is 16 mg/dL.

The patient's acid-base status is abnormal, with a pH of 7.20 and a bicarbonate level of 15 mmol/L. His lactate level is 1.9 mmol/L, and his glucose level is 119 mg/dL.

The patient's condition is complicated by his history of bleeding and blood loss, which may have contributed to his anemia and acidosis. He also has a history of hypotension, which may have required the use of vasopressors.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Continued sepsis and septic shock
2. Acute kidney injury and worsening of renal function
3. Metabolic acidosis and electrolyte imbalances
4. Anemia and bleeding
5. Pneumonia and respiratory failure
6. Cardiovascular instability and arrhythmias
7. Increased risk of infections and sepsis due to the patient's immunocompromised state
8. Delayed healing and increased risk of complications due to the patient's advanced age and comorbidities.

Based on this information, I recommend the following:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy to cover possible bacterial and fungal infections.
2. Monitor the patient's acid-base status and electrolyte levels closely, and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent further complications.
3. Continue to provide respiratory support to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status closely, and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent further complications.
5. Consider consulting with a nephrologist to optimize the patient's fluid management and electrolyte levels.
6. Consider consulting with a cardiologist to optimize the patient's cardiovascular management and prevent further complications.
7. Monitor the patient's nutritional status closely, and consider consulting with a nutritionist to optimize his caloric and protein intake.
8. Consider consulting with a palliative care team to optimize the patient's pain and symptom management.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

The patient is a critically ill individual with pneumonia, hypotension, respiratory failure, and acute renal failure. They are intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 12 cmH2O. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1Â°C, heart rate of 62 bpm, and blood pressure of 122/47 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is being closely monitored, with a respiratory rate of 18 inspirations per minute and a SpO2 of 99%.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, acute kidney injury, and metabolic acidosis. The patient's creatinine is rising, which is concerning for acute tubular necrosis (ATN). The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated lactate level.

The patient's physical examination is significant for bilateral peripheral edema, with no signs of cyanosis, clubbing, or muscle wasting. The patient's neurologic examination is significant for sedation, with no spontaneous movement or orientation.

The patient's medical history is significant for pneumonia, hypotension, respiratory failure, and acute renal failure. The patient has a history of anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.7 g/dL. The patient is receiving antibiotics, vasopressors, and sedatives.

Based on the patient's current condition, potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening of respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is already compromised, and further deterioration could lead to respiratory arrest.
2. Acute tubular necrosis: The patient's rising creatinine level is concerning for ATN, which could lead to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis could worsen if not addressed, leading to further compromise of organ function.
4. Infection: The patient's pneumonia could worsen, leading to sepsis or multi-organ failure.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension could worsen, leading to organ hypoperfusion and failure.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia could worsen, leading to further compromise of organ function.
7. Sedation: The patient's sedation could worsen, leading to respiratory depression or cardiac arrest.

Based on the patient's current condition, I recommend the following:

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, including respiratory rate, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation.
2. Adjust the patient's mechanical ventilation settings to optimize oxygenation and ventilation.
3. Continue antibiotic therapy for the patient's pneumonia.
4. Monitor the patient's creatinine level closely and consider dialysis if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely and correct any imbalances.
6. Consider weaning the patient off sedatives and switching to a non-invasive ventilation mode.
7. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusion if necessary.
8. Continue to provide supportive care, including fluid resuscitation and cardiovascular support, as needed.

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He was admitted to the ICU with sepsis, pneumonia, and acute kidney injury. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 12 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2Â°C, heart rate of 70 bpm, and blood pressure of 117/42 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.5 K/uL, with a bandemia, and a lactate level of 1.9 mmol/L. His serum creatinine has increased to 3.0 mg/dL, and his urine output is low. He is receiving IV fluids and vasopressors to maintain blood pressure and perfusion to his kidneys.

The patient's medical conditions include sepsis, pneumonia, metabolic acidosis, anemia, acute kidney injury, and new-onset atrial fibrillation. He is receiving treatment for these conditions, including antibiotics, vasopressors, and fluid resuscitation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to progress if not treated promptly and effectively.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is likely to worsen if not treated with appropriate antibiotics and supportive care.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely to worsen if not treated with appropriate fluid management and vasopressors.
4. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is likely to worsen if not treated with bicarbonate supplementation and correction of electrolyte imbalances.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely to worsen if not treated with blood transfusions and iron supplementation.
6. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely to worsen if not treated with anticoagulation therapy and rate control medications.
7. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia due to his prolonged mechanical ventilation and immunosuppressed state.
8. Deep Vein Thrombosis: The patient is at risk for deep vein thrombosis due to his immobility and prolonged hospitalization.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to treat the patient's sepsis, pneumonia, and acute kidney injury with appropriate antibiotics, vasopressors, and fluid resuscitation.
2. Monitor the patient's laboratory results closely to ensure that his metabolic acidosis, anemia, and atrial fibrillation are being effectively treated.
3. Consider consulting with a nephrologist to optimize the patient's fluid management and electrolyte supplementation.
4. Consider consulting with a cardiologist to optimize the patient's anticoagulation therapy and rate control medications.
5. Monitor the patient's urine output closely to ensure that his acute kidney injury is not worsening.
6. Consider consulting with a nutritionist to optimize the patient's nutrition and glycemic control.
7. Monitor the patient's blood pressure closely to ensure that it remains within a safe range.
8. Consider consulting with a pulmonologist to optimize the patient's mechanical ventilation and weaning strategy.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis, metabolic acidosis, anemia, pneumonia, and acute kidney injury. He has a history of papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. The patient was intubated and started on various antibiotics, including Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin. He has been receiving fluid resuscitation and vasopressor support, and his blood pressure has been maintained above 65 mmHg.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely related to pneumonia, and there is a risk of further deterioration if the infection is not adequately treated.
2. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's non-anion gap acidosis may worsen if his fluid resuscitation is not managed properly, leading to further acidosis and potential organ dysfunction.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if he continues to bleed or if his bone marrow function is compromised.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may worsen if his antibiotic treatment is inadequate or if he develops resistance to the antibiotics.
5. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen if he continues to receive nephrotoxic medications or if his blood pressure is not adequately managed.
6. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if his pneumonia is not adequately treated or if he develops respiratory muscle weakness.
7. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac status may worsen if he develops arrhythmias or if his cardiac function is compromised.
8. Neurological Complications: The patient's neurological status may worsen if he develops sepsis-related encephalopathy or if he has a stroke or other neurological event.
9. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's gastrointestinal status may worsen if he develops gastrointestinal bleeding or if he has a bowel obstruction.
10. Infection Control: The patient is at risk for further infections, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and may require additional measures to prevent these infections.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his various medical conditions to prevent further complications and improve his outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple comorbidities and ongoing medical issues.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2Â°C (99Â°F), heart rate of 70 beats per minute (bpm), and blood pressure of 117/42 mmHg. Respiratory support is provided through a tracheostomy tube and mechanical ventilation, with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50% and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 12 cmH2O.

The patient has a history of anemia secondary to blood loss, metabolic acidosis, hypotension, pneumonia, and bacterial community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The patient is receiving antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn), as well as other medications such as fentanyl, midazolam (Versed), and pantoprazole (Protonix).

The patient's laboratory results indicate a white blood cell count of 11.5, hemoglobin of 9.2 g/dL, and platelet count of 150. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with the exception of a slightly elevated potassium level of 4.6 mEq/L.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their critical condition, with no assessment of peripheral vascular, skin, neurologic, or other systems.

The patient's current medical complications and potential risks include:

1. Sepsis and septic shock due to bacterial pneumonia and possible secondary infections.
2. Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypotension, blood loss, and potential sepsis.
4. Anemia and potential bleeding complications due to blood loss and thrombocytopenia.
5. Metabolic acidosis and potential complications such as cardiac arrhythmias and decreased tissue perfusion.
6. Potential for further complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and stress ulcer bleeding.

The patient's current treatment plan includes continued antibiotic therapy, mechanical ventilation, and close monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and fluid balance. The patient's code status is do not resuscitate (DNR), and their disposition is pending further evaluation and treatment.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an elderly Asian male who has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation in the ICU. He has a history of pneumonia, anemia, and hypotension. 

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2Â°C, heart rate of 70 bpm, and blood pressure of 117/42 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 17 inspirations per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 98% on 50% FiO2.

The patient's physical examination reveals 3-6+ edema in the upper extremities, with a weak right radial pulse and a 2+ left radial pulse. His abdomen is soft, and his neurologic examination shows that he is intubated and spontaneously opens his eyes.

Laboratory results show anemia, acidosis, and elevated white blood cell count. His blood cultures are pending. 

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's pneumonia and elevated white blood cell count, there is a risk of developing sepsis.
2. Bleeding: The patient's anemia and history of blood loss increase the risk of bleeding complications.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's pneumonia and respiratory failure may lead to worsening respiratory function and potential need for more aggressive respiratory support.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's hypotension and anemia may lead to cardiac complications, such as decreased cardiac output and potential cardiac arrest.
5. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and respiratory failure increase the risk of developing secondary infections.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's inability to eat and receive adequate nutrition may lead to malnutrition and potential complications.
7. Skin breakdown: The patient's immobility and edema may lead to skin breakdown and potential pressure ulcers.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications and optimize his care.

   Assessment and Plan
   85 y.o. Male w/ papillary thyroid CA s/p thyroidectomy with radioactive
   iodine ablation, SCC of the larynx s/p total laryngectomy w/ modified
   radical neck dissection with stoma, metastatic prostate cancer with
   metastatic lesions to the bone presenting to the ED with 2day history
   of fevers, chills, fatigue, poor PO intake and non-productive cough now
   septic and intubated.
   #. Sepsis: On admission patient met SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   temperature of 102, tachypnea and white blood count with bandemia. WBC
   have increased to trended down to 6.6. however he still has impressive
   bandemia. Likely source of SIRS is pneumonia.  Lactate initially noted
   to be 6.1, however following fluid administration is 1.9. Pt was
   started on Levofloxacin, Cefepime, Vancomycin in the ED. Zosyn IV was
   started for broad coverage, Levofloxacin for atypical coverage,
   Vancomycin for MRSA coverage given his h.o. of MRSA. Yesterday he
   became hypotensive and required pressure support again with Levophed as
   well as frequent IVF boluses. Today he has been able to wean off the
   levophed gtt.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, Vancomycin, narrow spectrum if cultures
   turn positive; will increase vanc dosing to daily as his vanc trough
   was low today.
   - Sputum cx, bld cx pending. Legionella antigen negative, will send DFA
   for influenza.
   - Maintain MAP > 65, if pt requires vasopressor support will started
   levophed with vasopressin, will then attempt to wean off levophed and
   keep vasopressin for a 24 hour period.
   - Continue to trend WBC
   #. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a non-anion gap acidosis most
   likely related to his vast fluid resuscitation with normal saline.
   Following administration of 1L D5W with 3 amps of HCO3 pt
s CO2
   increased from 16 to 20. Will bolus IVF with LR and check PM lytes to
   monitor for hyperkalemia.
   - Support his BP as below to maintain pefusion to his kidneys.
   - IVF bolus with LR and monitor lytes for hyperkalemia.
   # Anemia: Pt has a history of Anemia prior Hcts late last year show
   approx 23. On admission Hct 24 likely artificially elevated [**3-5**]
   hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. Pt received 2units PRBC following a
   morning Hct of 15. Currently his Hct has been stable now at 30, will
   continue to monitor.
   - Active type and screen
   - Continue to monitor Hct
   # Pneumonia: Chest x-ray today looks worse. Hypotension returned
   yesterday requiring Levophed to be restarted. Pt started on ARDs
   protocol though he is taking in volume greater than 6cc/kg.  Urinary
   legionella negative.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, and Vancomycin with increased vanc
   dosing as above.
   - Sputum cultures, DFA ordered
   - Follow bcx as above
   - Continue vent support on pressure support and decrease sedation as
   CXR doesn
t show evidence of ARDS, wean as tolerated
   - Wean Versed and Fentanyl gtt as tolerated
   # New onset A-Fib: Pt noted to be in A-fib new onset in the ED which
   resolved once in the ICU.  He has been in sinus rhythm.
   - If A-fib recurs again at rate >100 consider starting digoxin vs
   amiodarone.
   - Monitor on tele
   # Acute Kidney Injury: The patient
s Cr furthered increased to 3.0,
   baseline Creatinine noted to be 1.1-1.2.  Urine lytes have been
   ordered, will again administer IVF boluses with LR given the pt
   non-anion gap metabolic acidosis from NS fluid resuscitationGiven low
   urine output [**Last Name (un) **] most likely [**3-5**] ATN versus pre-renal. Will continue to
   give fluid today and monitor UOP.
   - trend Cr

   likely require intubation for several days. ENT consulted yesterday for

   - Will consult ENT again today for trach placement as it is likely pt

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old male with a complex medical history, including papillary thyroid cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, and metastatic prostate cancer. He was admitted to the ICU with sepsis, pneumonia, and acute kidney injury. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation, vasopressor support, and antibiotics. His laboratory results show evidence of metabolic acidosis, anemia, and acute kidney injury.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to worsen if not adequately treated, leading to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is likely to worsen if not adequately treated, leading to respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely to worsen if not adequately treated, leading to further compromise of his renal function and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is likely to worsen if not adequately treated, leading to further compromise of his cardiac function and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely to worsen if not adequately treated, leading to further compromise of his cardiac function and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. New Onset A-Fib: The patient's new onset A-fib is likely to worsen if not adequately treated, leading to cardiac arrhythmias and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Trauma: The patient's trauma is likely to worsen if not adequately treated, leading to further compromise of his cardiac function and potentially life-threatening complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to treat the patient's sepsis, pneumonia, and acute kidney injury with appropriate antibiotics and fluids.
2. Monitor the patient's laboratory results closely to ensure that his metabolic acidosis, anemia, and acute kidney injury are being adequately treated.
3. Consider consulting a nephrologist to further manage the patient's acute kidney injury.
4. Consider consulting a cardiologist to further manage the patient's new onset A-fib.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust his medications as necessary to prevent further compromise of his cardiac function.
6. Consider consulting a trauma specialist to further manage the patient's trauma.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with a chief complaint of respiratory failure, pneumonia, acute renal failure, hypotension, and acidosis. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 12 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9Â°C, heart rate of 70 bpm, and blood pressure of 106/49 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support is being managed with a tracheostomy tube and a ventilator in CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow mode.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, acute kidney injury, and metabolic acidosis. The patient's creatinine level is stable, and the patient is receiving bicarbonate for hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. The patient's white blood cell count is slightly improved.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status can deteriorate further, leading to increased oxygen requirements, worsening of hypoxemia, or even respiratory arrest.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia can worsen, leading to increased inflammation, consolidation, or even sepsis.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure can progress, leading to worsening of electrolyte imbalance, acidosis, or even end-stage renal disease.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension can worsen, leading to decreased perfusion, organ dysfunction, or even cardiogenic shock.
5. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis can worsen, leading to increased lactate production, decreased buffering capacity, or even cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen, leading to decreased oxygen delivery, increased cardiac workload, or even cardiovascular instability.
7. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis can develop or worsen, leading to increased inflammation, organ dysfunction, or even multi-organ failure.
8. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular status can deteriorate, leading to decreased cardiac output, increased blood pressure, or even cardiac arrest.
9. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status can deteriorate, leading to decreased level of consciousness, increased intracranial pressure, or even cerebral edema.
10. Infection: The patient can develop secondary infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, catheter-related bloodstream infections, or other infections that can worsen their condition.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   85 y.o. Male w/ papillary thyroid CA s/p thyroidectomy with radioactive
   iodine ablation, SCC of the larynx s/p total laryngectomy w/ modified
   radical neck dissection with stoma, metastatic prostate cancer with
   metastatic lesions to the bone presenting to the ED with 2day history
   of fevers, chills, fatigue, poor PO intake and non-productive cough now
   septic and intubated.
   #. Sepsis: On admission patient met SIRS criteria with tachycardia,
   temperature of 102, tachypnea and white blood count with bandemia. WBC
   have increased to trended down to 6.6. however he still has impressive
   bandemia. Likely source of SIRS is pneumonia.  Lactate initially noted
   to be 6.1, however following fluid administration is 1.9. Pt was
   started on Levofloxacin, Cefepime, Vancomycin in the ED. Zosyn IV was
   started for broad coverage, Levofloxacin for atypical coverage,
   Vancomycin for MRSA coverage given his h.o. of MRSA. Yesterday he
   became hypotensive and required pressure support again with Levophed as
   well as frequent IVF boluses. Today he has been able to wean off the
   levophed gtt.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, narrow spectrum if cultures turn
   positive
   - will d/c Vancomycin as MRSA screen negative
   - Sputum cx, bld cx pending. Legionella antigen negative, DFA for
   influenza pending.
   - Maintain MAP > 65, if pt requires vasopressor support will started
   levophed with vasopressin, will then attempt to wean off levophed and
   keep vasopressin for a 24 hour period. Will start pt on bolus of LR for
   IVF resuscitation.
   - Continue to trend WBC
   #. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a non-anion gap acidosis most
   likely related to his vast fluid resuscitation with normal saline.
   Following administration of 1L D5W with 3 amps of HCO3 pt
s CO2
   increased from 16 to 20. Will bolus IVF with LR and check PM lytes to
   monitor for hyperkalemia.
   - Support his BP as below to maintain pefusion to his kidneys.
   - IVF bolus with LR and monitor lytes for hyperkalemia.
   # Anemia: Pt has a history of Anemia prior Hcts late last year show
   approx 23. On admission Hct 24 likely artificially elevated [**3-5**]
   hypovolemia/hemoconcentration. Pt received 2units PRBC following a
   morning Hct of 15. Currently his Hct has been stable now at 30, will
   continue to monitor.  As pt has had not decrease in Hct over the past
   few days, will restart Heparin for prophylaxis.
   - Active type and screen
   - Continue to monitor Hct
   # Pneumonia: Culture data thus far negative to date. Pt started on ARDs
   protocol though he is taking in volume greater than 6cc/kg.  Urinary
   legionella negative.
   - Continue Zosyn, Levofloxacin, will d/c Vancomycin as MRSA swab was
   negative
   - Sputum cultures, DFA negative
   - Follow bcx as above
   - Will decrease FiO2 now and see how pt tolerates FiO2 of 40%. Will
   also aim to decrease PEEP from 12 to 8 with the goal of transitioning
   to trach mask with frequent suctioning of secretions.
   - Wean Versed and Fentanyl gtt as tolerated
   # Nutrition: Pt has been without nutrition, will consult nutrition
   regarding TF via NGT.
   - Nutrition consult for TF
   # New onset A-Fib: Pt noted to be in A-fib new onset in the ED which
   resolved once in the ICU.  He has been in sinus rhythm.
   - If A-fib recurs again at rate >100 consider starting digoxin vs
   amiodarone.
   - Monitor on tele
   # Acute Kidney Injury: The patient
s Cr furthered increased to 3.0,
   baseline Creatinine noted to be 1.1-1.2.  Pt
s Creatinine with fluid
   resuscitation with urin output approx 50cc showed a decrease to 2.3,
